Il Rapporto SDGs 2025 dell‚ÄôIstat √® uno strumento prezioso per comprendere a che punto si trovi l‚ÄôItalia nel cammino verso il raggiungimento degli Obiettivi di Sviluppo Sostenibile (SDGs) dell‚ÄôAgenda 2030 delle Nazioni Unite.

Istat e SDGs: una fotografia dell‚ÄôItalia sostenibile

La buona notizia √® che ci sono segnali di miglioramento, ma la cattiva √® che non bastano.

Il quadro che emerge dal Rapporto √® variegato: se da un lato alcuni indicatori mostrano progressi, dall‚Äôaltro restano criticit√† importanti, specialmente nel Mezzogiorno e su temi cruciali come lavoro, disuguaglianze, salute, risorse naturali e infrastrutture.

Obiettivi di Sviluppo Sostenibile (SDGs)

Il documento, frutto di una collaborazione tra Istat, Sistan e soggetti esterni, diffonde 320 misure statistiche collegate a 148 indicatori globali SDGs.: il sistema Istat-SDGs appare quindi come una fonte affidabile per chiunque voglia analizzare o orientare le politiche pubbliche in chiave sostenibile.

SDGs in Italia: le sfide principali tre lentezze, crisi e squilibri territoriali

A frenare la corsa verso gli SDGs sono stati eventi globali come la pandemia, le tensioni geopolitiche e l‚Äôinflazione, che hanno deviato attenzione e risorse dagli obiettivi dell‚ÄôAgenda 2030.

Il recente Accordo di Siviglia, sottoscritto alla V Conferenza ONU sul Finanziamento allo Sviluppo, ha rilanciato l‚Äôurgenza di reindirizzare i flussi finanziari globali verso sviluppo sostenibile e transizione verde.

SDGs in Italia: i numeri della sostenibilit√† italiana

Nel Nord Italia, alcune regioni si distinguono chiaramente per le loro performance positive. Valle d‚ÄôAosta, Lombardia e Friuli-Venezia Giulia registrano una quota molto elevata di misure in posizione favorevole ‚Äì oltre la met√† degli indicatori ‚Äì, contribuendo in modo significativo ai buoni risultati raggiunti soprattutto nei Goal 1 (lotta alla povert√†) e Goal 8 (lavoro dignitoso e crescita economica).

Anche Emilia-Romagna e le Province autonome di Trento e Bolzano/Bozen mostrano andamenti particolarmente positivi, soprattutto per quanto riguarda il Goal 10 (riduzione delle disuguaglianze di reddito) e il Goal 6 (uso efficiente delle risorse idriche).

Situazione diversa per la Liguria, che presenta risultati meno favorevoli, in particolare nei Goal 5 (parit√† di genere), con un tasso di abortivit√† volontaria superiore alla media, nel Goal 13 (lotta al cambiamento climatico), con elevato rischio frane, e nel Goal 16 (giustizia e istituzioni solide), a causa dell‚Äôalto numero di detenuti in attesa di primo giudizio.

Spostandoci nel Centro Italia, le regioni Marche e Toscana si distinguono per una presenza significativa di indicatori positivi ‚Äì rispettivamente nel 55% e nel 50% delle misure analizzate. I risultati migliori si osservano nei Goal 1, 8 e 10, ma anche nel Goal 2 (fame zero), segnalando un equilibrio tra benessere economico, inclusione sociale e sicurezza alimentare.

Al contrario, il Lazio evidenzia alcune criticit√†, in particolare nei Goal 5 e 10, ma soprattutto nel Goal 16, dove nessuno degli indicatori supera la media nazionale. Un dato emblematico riguarda l‚Äôalta incidenza di persone residenti non registrate in anagrafe, che incide negativamente su vari aspetti di inclusione e legalit√†.

Nel Mezzogiorno, il quadro √® pi√π frammentato. In generale, solo poco pi√π di un quarto delle misure risulta al di sopra della media nazionale. Tuttavia, alcune regioni si distinguono positivamente: Abruzzo, Molise e Basilicata ottengono risultati incoraggianti, con almeno un terzo delle misure in miglioramento, soprattutto nei Goal ambientali (13, 14 e 15).

Un contributo importante viene dalle aree naturali protette, che rappresentano un punto di forza per la sostenibilit√† del territorio. Puglia eccelle nel Goal 14 (vita sott‚Äôacqua), grazie all‚Äôelevata qualit√† delle acque di balneazione, mentre la Calabria si distingue per buoni risultati nel Goal 15 (vita sulla terra).

Anche Sardegna e Sicilia offrono segnali positivi, in particolare nel Goal 2, dove il miglioramento √® legato alla crescita delle coltivazioni biologiche, a testimonianza di una maggiore attenzione verso pratiche agricole sostenibili.

Fonte; pexels.com

Stato degli SDGs in Italia: analisi di dettaglio

Entrando nel dettaglio dei singoli Goal, vediamo come si stia evolvendo ciascuno dei 17 Obiettivi di Sviluppo Sostenibile:

Goal 1 - Porre fine alla povert√†

9,7% della popolazione in povert√† assoluta nel 2023.

18,9% a rischio povert√† nel 2024, con picchi tra i giovani (23,2%).

Goal 2 - Fame zero

1,3% degli italiani soffre di insicurezza alimentare, con il dato che sale al 2,7% nel Mezzogiorno.

Goal 3 - Salute e benessere

Speranza di vita: 83,4 anni.

Speranza di vita in buona salute in calo: 58,1 anni.

Mortalit√† per malattie croniche in diminuzione.

Goal 4 - Istruzione di qualit√†

32,8% degli alunni di II primaria non raggiunge la soglia minima in italiano.

Early leavers in calo: 9,8% nel 2024, vicini al target 2030.

Goal 5 - Uguaglianza di genere

94 femminicidi nel 2023. Cresce l‚Äôofferta di centri antiviolenza e la rappresentanza femminile.

Goal 6 - Acqua pulita e servizi igienico-sanitari

L‚ÄôItalia √® prima in UE per consumo d‚Äôacqua potabile.

Rete idrica poco efficiente: perdite superiori al 40%.

28,7% delle famiglie non si fida dell‚Äôacqua del rubinetto.

Goal 7 - Energia pulita e accessibile

FER al 19,6% (obiettivo 2030: 39,4%). Vediamo consumi residenziali in calo, ma crollano le vendite di auto elettriche (7,5%).

Goal 8 - Lavoro dignitoso e crescita economica

Buone performance nel Nord, ma il Sud resta in svantaggio. Crescono, invece, gli indicatori su occupazione e produttivit√†.

Goal 9 - Industria, innovazione e infrastrutture

I progressi restano limitati. Infatti, il supporto all‚Äôinnovazione, soprattutto green, √® ancora insufficiente.

Goal 10 - Ridurre le disuguaglianze

Il Mezzogiorno √® in netto svantaggio: oltre il 60% degli indicatori peggiori della media nazionale.

Goal 11 - Citt√† e comunit√† sostenibili

Progressi su qualit√† della vita e mobilit√†, ma persistono criticit√† in aree periferiche.

Goal 12 - Consumo e produzione responsabili

Segnali positivi, ma alcune regioni del Nord mostrano performance sotto la media.

Goal 13 - Lotta contro il cambiamento climatico

Miglioramenti sugli indicatori energetici e sulle emissioni.

Rallentamento nei progressi verso gli obiettivi dell‚ÄôAccordo di Parigi.

Goal 14 - Vita sott‚Äôacqua

Qualit√† delle acque eccellente in regioni come Puglia e Sardegna.

Il Nord mostra maggiori difficolt√†.

Goal 15 - Vita sulla terra

√à il Goal pi√π statico: 89% delle misure sono stabili o in peggioramento. Ma vediamo la Calabria in controtendenza con segnali positivi.

Goal 16 - Pace, giustizia e istituzioni solide

Peggioramenti nel 60% degli indicatori, soprattutto nel Lazio.

Alta incidenza di popolazione non registrata in anagrafe.

Goal 17 - Partnership per gli obiettivi

Uno dei Goal con i migliori miglioramenti, grazie alla cooperazione nazionale e internazionale.

Stato degli SDGs in Italia: conclusioni

Il Rapporto SDGs 2025 √® un richiamo forte e chiaro: se non ci sar√† un cambio di passo, l‚ÄôItalia rischia di mancare gli obiettivi dell‚ÄôAgenda 2030.

Le sfide da affrontare riguardano innovazione, infrastrutture, equit√† sociale, transizione energetica e istruzione.

Progettiamo insieme una strategia efficace e sostenibile: scopri di pi√π

US-CoastEX: Observation-based probabilistic reanalysis of storm surge and sea level extremes for the United States
                    Joao Morim1,2, D. J. Rasmussen3, Thomas Wahl¬†
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-3643-54631,2, Francisco M. Calafat¬†
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-7474-135X4,5, Robert E. Kopp6, Michael Oppenheimer7 & ‚Ä¶Soenke Dangendorf¬†

            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Climate changeEnvironmental impactNatural hazardsPhysical oceanography

AbstractReliable estimates of storm surge and sea level extremes with proper uncertainty quantification are key for cost-effective risk/adaptation planning. However, observational estimates are often unavailable or uncertain along most coastlines owing to data scarcity. Here, we provide a fully observational-driven probabilistic dataset (US-CoastEX) of storm surge and sea level extremes for the U.S. coast (1950‚Äì2020). Non-stationary extreme storm surge distributions are generated for gauged and ungauged sites by applying Bayesian methods to the U.S. tide gauge network, complemented with additional storm data unavailable in commonly used tide gauge data. The distributions are combined with tidal peak data to estimate return periods and levels of extreme sea levels and their uncertainty. Ou results show that traditional site-by-site estimates based on existing model data, as well as regionally-aggregated analysis of standard tide gauge data, have underestimated 100-year extreme sea levels by 50% (on average) along much of the U.S. coast, especially in regions exposed to extreme storms. The data supports coastal managers to make decisions, especially in vulnerable areas where in-situ sea-level monitoring is limited.

                        Background & SummaryExtreme sea level (ESL) events caused by storm surge extremes pose a threat to many coastal populations and natural ecosystems1 especially when combined with high astronomical tides1,2. The most extreme storm surge events develop during major storms, such as hurricanes and/or powerful extratropical storms, when extreme winds and low atmospheric pressure push ocean water ashore1,2. Establishing robust estimates of storm surge and extreme sea level events with proper uncertainty quantification through statistical analysis of observational data is critical for coastal design and risk and adaptation assessments3. However, high-quality historical sea-level observations are only available at sites with tide gauges, leaving long coastal stretches without observational coverage3,4,5. Furthermore, most tide gauges contain only a few years, or decades, of data, thereby providing only a limited sample of extremes. They also usually comprise gaps and/or erroneous or incomplete readings during major storms such as hurricane events4,5,6. These limitations limit reliable estimates of the likelihoods of extreme events (and their changes over time) using site-by-site statistical analysis of observational data4,5,6.Global and regional storm surge hindcasts, and extended data-reconstructions from machine-learning methods, based on atmospheric reanalysis forcing fields provide spatially-continuous extreme data from which extreme value statistics can be obtained. However, such products tend to underestimate coastal storm surge extremes, partly due to their coarse resolution atmospheric reanalysis forcing that cannot properly resolve extreme values6,7,8,9 and generally exhibit spurious climate variability and trends due to interplays between model biases and changes in historical observational data in reanalysis products9,10,11,12. In addition, as with most tide gauge data, existing storm surge hindcasts generally cover a few decades, typically after 1980 when satellite records began to become available to constrain atmospheric reanalyses12. Spatial statistical approaches such as regional frequency analysis (RFA)13,14,15 offer an alternative to partially overcome several sampling limitations of traditional site-by-site analysis of storm extremes by fitting a particular extreme value distribution to sets of aggregated storm data pooled together (from tide gauges sites or model outputs) across coastal regions that are assumed to be coherent. However, while easy to apply, RFA approaches rely on subjective criteria to establish coastal sites with coherent extreme storm characteristics13,14,15 and suffer from unsubstantiated statistical assumptions (e.g., neglecting spatial inter-site dependences and relying on unrealistic regional limits that generate discontinuous extreme storm surge fields)13,14,15, which often result in unreliable estimates and/or misrepresented uncertainties.Recently, more advanced spatial models for storm extremes have been used to overcome such limitations by resolving spatial dependencies in extremes, and in turn, enabling sharing of data information across tide gauge sites, and enabling predictions of surge extremes for ungauged sites4,5,16,17. However, existing spatial models (and associated data sets) for the U.S. have relied on a limited number of long-term tide gauge data16,17, thereby suffering from similar problems as site-by-site analyses, and are limited to contiguous U.S. regions which creates a limited basis situation for future coastal planning5. These models have also assumed that surge extremes are stationary16,17 whilst surge extremes have been shown to have regional coherent and significant trends along widespread U.S. coastal regions18. These current limitations preclude robust flood risk assessment and cost-effective adaptation planning with potentially severe implications due to premature failure of flood defenses designed with erroneous predictions19. Consequently, there is an urgent need for more reliable and robust estimates of the occurrence probabilities of storm surge and sea level extremes with a rigorous treatment of uncertainty. This should also account for major storm extremes that happened in the past, but are not captured and resolved in commonly used coastal water level databases.Here, we present a new observation-based probabilistic dataset (‚ÄúUS-CoastEX‚Äù) of storm surge and sea level extremes along the entire U.S coastline by applying an established non-stationary spatiotemporal Bayesian Hierarchical Framework (BAYEX)4 to the U.S. tide gauge network18 between 1950‚Äì2020. The complete dataset comprises two different versions: a standard version in which BAYEX is informed solely with high-quality tide gauge record data18 and an extended version where additional records from other sources (including sub-hourly tide gauge records, inferred extremes, last recorded water levels or high-water marks) are processed and also used to support BAYEX in addition to the standard hourly tide gauge records. BAYEX resolves tide gauge dependences in space and time and models extreme storm surge fields as a nonstationary continuous process consistent with underlying climatological storm patterns. The consideration for such dependences in BAYEX compensates for data spareness (i.e., allows accommodation of data gaps), reduces uncertainty for coastal gauged sites and enables estimates of storm surge distribution data for ungauged sites4,18.In addition to providing storm surge data, our dataset also contains ESL return period estimates estimated by combining BAYEX-inferred skew surge distribution data with astronomical tidal distributions. These estimates are compared to published ESL estimates used to inform coastal hazard and/or risk flood assessments, highlighting that return levels and return periods of ESL events have been underpredicted on widespread U.S. coastal regions relative to other products.The data provided can support coastal managers to make more confident decisions, especially along many U.S. coastlines that are vulnerable and where long-term in-situ sea level monitoring is limited or non-existent. Our fully-empirical dataset provides supports for a range of coastal engineering and science needs (e.g., engineering design/management and coastal flood hazard and risk analysis). It provides, for instance, a new benchmark for validation of storm extremes and flood hazard estimates generated through numerical modeling (based on reanalysis climate data, synthetic storms or climate model projections) and extended data-reconstructions. It could also be directly combined with other relevant meteorological, hydrological and/or oceanographic extremes (e.g., rainfall and wind-waves) to estimate total water levels and other¬†compound extremes. Thus, it fills an important gap, particularly for U.S. coastal regions such as Hawaii, Alaska, Puerto Rico/U.S Virgin Islands where historical in-situ sea level monitoring is limited or even non-existent (and which have been usually excluded from coastal climate assessments18). A summary of the data in US-CoastEX is fully described in Supplementary Information.MethodsBayesian Hierarchical Modeling with BAYEXThe BAYEX framework4 performs spatiotemporal Bayesian hierarchical modeling of coastal storm surge extremes and is represented as a product of conditional distributions or sub-models, or layers. These comprise: (1) an ‚Äúobservation model‚Äù that links the prescribed extreme data to the spatio-temporal processes; (2) a ‚Äúprocess model‚Äù that accounts for underlying dynamics of the processes involved; and (3) a ‚Äúparameter model‚Äù that considers the underlying uncertainties in the parameters and integrates any prior knowledge about the prescribed data and underlying processes. The hierarchical model structure enables the assessment of the joint distribution of the processes and parameters conditioned on the data (also known as the posterior distribution), while rigorously propagating the uncertainties underlying the data, processes, and parameters4. These types of Bayesian Hierarchical Models (BMH) have been applied across various science disciplines (e.g., hydrology20 and ecology21) to enable robust statistical estimates, especially in contexts characterized by data scarcity and high uncertainty.In modeling spatial inter-site dependences of storm surge extremes, BAYEX resolves residual dependence (sites with co-occurrence of storm extremes) and climatological dependence (sites with similar and/or consistent storminess but not necessarily co-occurrence of storm extremes). Residual dependence is resolved using a max-stable process4,16,22 (i.e., an infinite-dimensional generalization of a Generalized Extreme Value (GEV) distribution) and storm climatological dependence is here captured using latent Gaussian processes with random effects and physical bathymetric covariates (continental shelf width estimated using Natural Earth 200-meter depth contour line)4. In other words, residual dependence implies dependence among annual maxima whereas climatological dependence reflects spatial association amongst the GEV parameters4. The marginal distribution at any particular site follows a univariate GEV distribution based on max-stable process theory, with parameters Œº (location), œÉ (scale), and Œæ (shape). The location parameter, Œº, is modelled as a spatial time-evolving process (using an integrated random walk) to account for climatological storm frequency changes. The GEV scale and shape parameters follow a spatial-varying, stationary process. An extensive description of BAYEX including its formulation, implementation and testing, has already been provided elsewhere4,14, and thus we only provide a brief description of its observation and process model layers. The likelihood can be written as4,22:$${Y}_{t}\left({s}_{i}\right)|{\theta }_{t}\left({s}_{i}\right),{\mu }_{t}\left({s}_{i}\right),\sigma \left({s}_{i}\right),\xi ({s}_{i}),\alpha  \sim {GEV}\left({\mu }_{t}^{* }\left({s}_{i}\right),{\sigma }_{t}^{* }\left({s}_{i}\right),\alpha {\xi }^{* }({s}_{i})\right),$$
                    (1)
                $${\mu }_{t}^{* }\left(s\right)={\mu }_{t}\left(s\right)+\frac{\sigma (s)}{\xi }\left({{\theta }_{t}\left(s\right)}^{\xi (s)}-1\right),$$
                    (2)
                $${\sigma }_{t}^{* }\left({s}_{i}\right)=\alpha \sigma \left(s\right){{\theta }_{t}\left(s\right)}^{\xi \left(s\right)},$$
                    (3)
                where \({Y}_{t}\left({s}_{i}\right)\) is the annual maximum surge (m) for year \(t\) at site \({s}_{i}\), and \({\theta }_{t}\left(s\right)\) is a spatial process resolving residual dependence and \(\alpha \)‚Äâ‚àà‚Äâ(0,1) is a parameter that controls the relative contribution of small-scale errors. The GEV shape parameter, Œæ, is allowed to vary in space, according to a Gaussian process18:$$\xi (s) \sim GP(\underline{\xi },c(s,s{\prime} ;{\gamma }_{\xi },{\rho }_{\xi })),$$
                    (4)
                where \(GP(\underline{\xi },c(s,s{\prime} ;{\gamma }_{\xi },{\rho }_{\xi }))\) is a Gaussian process with mean \(\underline{\xi }\) and covariance function c(,‚àô). The hyperparameters \({\gamma }_{\xi }\) and \({\rho }_{\xi }\) denote, respectively, standard deviation and length scale values defining the covariance function4.The GEV location parameter \({\mu }_{t}\left(s\right)\) is assumed to vary smoothly through time (to resolve long-term changes such as nonlinear trends as opposed to shorter-term variations, which are likely unresolvable) using a spatio-temporal integrated random walk according to4:$${\mu }_{t}\left(s\right)={\mu }_{t-1}\left(s\right)+{\mu }_{{trend},t-1}\left(s\right),$$
                    (5)
                $${\mu }_{{trend},t}\left(s\right)={\mu }_{{trend},t-1}\left(s\right)+{\omega }_{t}\left(s\right),$$
                    (6)
                where \({\omega }_{t}\left(s\right)\) is a zero-mean Gaussian process \({\omega }_{t}\left(s\right) \sim {GP}\left(0,c\left(s,s{\prime} ;{\gamma }_{\mu },{\rho }_{\mu }\right)\right)\).The extended description of all BAYEX process layers and parameters, including all Gaussian processes and initial states of \(\mu \), see refs. 4,5. The full description of the BAYEX spatial domain and the statistical inference process and model diagnostics analysis has been provided in ref. 18. In total, 6,000 distribution samples (post-warm-up draws for analysis) are provided by BAYEX (after a warm-up phase) for gauged and ungauged sites along the U.S. coastline (Fig.¬†S1)18.Observational data for BAYEXUS-CoastEX includes extreme skew surge distributions (Fig.¬†S3 shows posterior-median and 90% credible intervals) in addition to ESL estimates derived through BAYEX based on annual maximum skew surge data obtained from different data sources (Tables¬†S1-S2) as shown below and illustrated in Fig.¬†1.Fig. 1Methodological framework diagram. The orange-shaded section displays the general workflow used to generate BAYESL-TG/EXT while the blue-shaded section shows the general workflow used to estimate the extreme sea level data from BAYESL-TG/EXT. The application of BAYES-TG uses only annual maxima skew surge data from observed hourly tide gauge sea-level records (as shown by the dashed violet line and the asterisk ‚Äò*‚Äô).Full size imageStandard version (BAYESL-TG)In the standard application of BAYEX (henceforth BAYESL-TG), the model is informed solely by historical time series of annual maxima skew surge (used synonymously with storm surge) derived from high quality hourly sea-level records (1950‚Äì2020) from 208 open-coast tide gauge sites included in the GESLA-2 (Global Extreme Sea Level Analysis) database (retrieved from: https://www.bodc.ac.uk/resources/inventories/edmed/report/6562/)23 (Figs.¬†S1, S2). Skew surge (defined as the absolute difference between observed high-water level and the closest predicted high tide regardless of their timing over a tidal cycle) has been shown to be a reliable metric of storm surge under different tidal regimes24. Note that tide gauge data included in GESLA-2 are very similar to records in GESLA-3, as most updates and new data are for estuarine, river and lake regions, which are not used here, as further discussed below. We require 70% of all hourly records over a given year to determine an annual maximum. We remove any underlying mean sea level changes and its underlying variability by removing a centered 30-day moving average from the observed water level data. The data is also visually scrutinized and the corrected when required for any datum shifts and tsunamis. The tidal signal was extracted using a year-by-year harmonic analysis. This analysis is entirely focused on open-coastal regions where storm surge extremes are mainly driven by wind and pressure effects. Therefore, only tide gauges within a maximum of 5‚Äâkm from a coastline are used and locations further within deltas, narrow inlets, bays and tidal rivers, have been removed to minimize major effects of hyper-local geography, river discharge and/or nonlinear interactions which generally lead to very different storm surge extremes than events experienced along open-coastal regions. The full description of the data processing is available elsewhere18. The exact location of the tide gauge sites, and their record length, are shown in Fig.¬†S1. The samples of GEV model parameters (summarized as posterior-medians and 90% CI within Fig.¬†S3) and annual maxima from BAYESL-TG/EXT are archived without further processing (Table¬†S3). A full discussion of BAYESL-TG extreme skew surge data is also provided in ref. 18.Extended version (BAYS-TG/EXT)Hourly tide gauge records provide high-quality ESL information but since they generally have hourly resolution, they could miss absolute peaks of storm events when there are larger changes in water levels at sub-hourly levels, as occurs more often during major events. In addition, it is well documented that during major storms (e.g., Camille and Katrina) there is typically missing data due to tide gauge damage or malfunction25,26. Hence, we provide an extended-data version (BAYESL-TG/Extended) where BAYEX has been informed not only by historical time series of annual maxima skew surge from hourly sea-level records, but also with extreme surges from NOAA top-ten water level data archives (https://api.tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/dpapi/prod/)27, including 6-min tide gauge records (after 1996), inferred extremes (derived through gap-filling procedures due to missing data), last recorded extreme water levels (last successfully recorded level before tide gauge malfunction during a storm) and high water marks and storm-tide peaks from SURGEDAT‚Äôs database (https://surge.climate.lsu.edu/data.html#GlobalMap) (Tables¬†S1-S2)26. In Fig.¬†1 (and Table¬†S1 and Fig.¬†S4) we present a brief comparison of BAYESL-TG and BAYESL-TG/EXT. The top-ten water-level information data from NOAA contains tide gauge codes, station names, peak dates & times, height, datum (MSL) and source27. The SURGEDAT data26 provides location, year and datum (for specific events) and recorded (or observed) water level data. Storm surge events before 1950 and after 2020 have been removed for consistency. Storm events retrieved from SURGEDAT26 are only considered when reported as ‚Äòstorm tides‚Äô (without breaking wind-wave influence) and with datum (described as height relative to normal tides, i.e., MSL) and their documented locations are within 20 miles from a tide gauge. The peak date and time are retrieved from NOAA‚Äôs extreme water level meteorological reports and confirmed using historical hurricane track data28. Any extreme events prior to 2020 have been updated (or corrected) to present-day MSL (2020) by adding MSL rise between the year of the recorded events and 2020) using relative MSL trends estimated by NOAA. There are a few tide gauge locations where no relative MSL trends are available and thus the values from the nearest tide gauge locations are used. The skew surge associated with each extreme water level event is determined by removing the closest tidal peak values extracted from NOAA‚Äôs tide prediction records, using their respective peak date and time, with all events brought to the same reference datum (MSL). For events where peak times are not provided (or available), tidal peak averages from that particular day have been used. In total, 1084 skew surge events have been estimated. We then compare these values with annual maxima skew surges previously estimated for those years using hourly tide gauge data, i.e., used to inform BAYESL-TG as previously described. The highest values within each year are therefore used as annual maxima. In total, 775 annual maxima skew surge values estimated from hourly tide gauge data are replaced by new, updated annual maxima skew surges, 652 obtained from processed NOAA top-ten water-level data, 2 from NOAA NWS data archives, and 7 from the SURGEDAT (Table¬†S2). BAYESL-TG/EXT (extended version) and BAYESL-TG (standard version) use the same values for Alaska, Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands, since no relevant annual maxima events have been identified across other complementary data sources (i.e., compared against annual maxima obtained from standard hourly tide gauge records). The GEV parameters associated with BAYESL-TG and BAYESL-TG/EXT are archived without further processing (see Table¬†S3).Estimation of ESL return levels using BAYEX outputsESL occurrences depend upon tidal processes and storm surges29. Here we use two approaches that are typically used to calculate ESL return levels from skew surge and tidal data29. The first approach (henceforth ‚ÄúMethod 1‚Äù) convolves the probability distributions of deterministic tidal peak data and stochastic storm surge data. This convolution approach allows us to use complete tidal information, which is not possible through direct analysis of still water levels (Fig.¬†S5)29. The probability of a given ESL event is thereafter derived from the joint cumulative distribution function. The convolution integral is given by29:$$F\left(z\right)=\int {G}_{r}\left(z-x\right)f\left(x\right){dx}$$
                    (7)
                where \({G}_{r}\) is the (GEV) distribution of extreme skew surges and \(f\) is the density function of the tidal peaks over a full 18.61-year nodal tidal cycle. This approach assumes skew surge and tide independence with an equal probability of a given skew surge occurring at any high tide28. We convolve 6,000 skew surge distribution samples from BAYEX with tidal peak data, generating a total of 6,000 ESL return period curves from which posterior-median values and associated 90% credible intervals are calculated. The second approach (henceforth Method 2) adds a fixed tide level (such as Mean High Water (MHW), Mean Higher High Water (MHHW), or Highest Astronomical Tide (HAT)) (Fig.¬†S6) to estimates of extreme surge levels9,23. Although we use Method 1 as reference in this analysis, we also provide alternative ESL estimates derived using fixed tide levels MHW, MHHW, and HAT (Fig.¬†S6), aligning with previous research15,29; but other tidal levels could be used. The observed tidal peaks at gauged locations are obtained from GESLA water level time series via harmonic analysis (using the same time series from which annual maxima skew surge levels are obtained to inform BAYEX). Tide gauge sites are often 10‚Äâs to 100‚Äâs‚Äâkm apart from each and prone to missing and/or underestimating peaks due to storms making landfall between gauged sites. In addition, as previously discussed, hourly tide gauge data can miss absolute peaks of storm events at sub-hourly scales and/or generally comprise gaps and erroneous and/or incomplete readings during major storms including hurricanes (e.g., Katrina and Camille)4,5,6 owing to tide gauge damage25. These results evidence that including additional observational sources of data is vital to enhancing estimates of storm surge and sea level extremes and that assessments relying entirely on hourly tide gauge observational data32,33 could result in unpredicted higher return periods particularly in coastal regions exposed to TC events. This includes physical models that (generally) bias-adjust storm surge outputs and are validated based on tide gauge data34,35.               The code that implements BAYEX is archived at Zenodo37.Data considerationsIt must be mentioned, as previously discussed, that BAYESL-TG and BAYESL-TG/EXT have been developed for open-coast regions using only tide gauge data within less than 5‚Äâkm from a coast. The application of BAYEX to the U.S. coastline15 (and associated data sets) (BAYESL-TG and BAYESL-TG/EXT) are hence not representative (or been tested or validated) of storm surge and sea level extremes in deltas, narrow inlets, bays and/or tidal rivers where hyperlocal geography, extensive river discharge, tidal influences and/or other nonlinear interactions could play a role. It should be noted though that a few specific tide gauges (with long-term data) used to inform BAYEX located within less than 5‚Äâkm of a coast could still be affected by hyperlocal geography (e.g., New York and Delaware). It is also important to mention that that storm surge and tides are just two contributors to total water levels that result in flooding. The data provided here are for storm surge extremes (and sea level extremes) but coastal design/risk assessments often require total coastal water levels. These may be derived by combining BAYEX data with other relevant meteorological and/or oceanographic water level contributors (e.g., rainfall and wave setup) (and their associated uncertainty) with total water level products.Complementary data sourcesBAYESL-TG/EXT is informed not only by historical time series of annual maxima skew surge from hourly sea level records but also with complementary annual maxima data processed from NOAA top-ten water level and SURGEDAT archives (Tables¬†S1-S2). That includes 6-min tide gauge records (after 1996), inferred extremes (determined using gap-filling procedures due to missing data), last successfully recorded extreme water levels prior to tide gauge malfunction during a storm and high water marks27 and historical storm-tide peaks from SURGEDAT peak surge database (Table¬†S1-S2)26. The inclusion of multiple major TC storms (e.g., that produced maximum surge levels‚Äâ>‚Äâ4‚Äâm; Hazel, Katrina or Camille) and other relevant events that do not exist in tide gauge records along with other relevant storms that have not been fully represented (and hence underestimated) by standard hourly tide gauge data result in much higher estimates compared to our standard BAYESL-TG version data (see Fig.¬†4; Fig.¬†S4). Although we derive annual maxima skew surges only for storms with reported locations and datums (as previously mentioned), there is a degree of uncertainty introduced for specific inferred extremes and high-water marks where processing techniques have been applied (e.g., gap-filling procedures from NOAA) or when the exact peak time of major hurricanes are not reported (e.g., SURGEDAT) and therefore daily tidal peak needs to be averaged to derive skew surge estimates. It could also be possible that the few high-water marks labeled in SURGEDAT as storm-tides (without wave breaking influence) might still contain a wave-related component. It should be noted, however, that these uncertainties are rather small relative to the uncertainties associated with storm surge levels resulting from major storms. This is the case of many coastal areas exposed to major TC events (e.g., U.S. Gulf coastline) where storm surge extremes exceed 4‚Äâm (e.g., Carla, Camile, Katrina and Rita; Fig.¬†S4) and differences between tidal peaks are extremely small (Fig.¬†S6).Model spatial knot gridThe Bayesian hierarchical model rigorously propagates the underlying uncertainties associated with the prescribed extreme data, processes and parameters. However, some considerations on the uncertainties associated with how we model residual dependence need to be discussed. The spatial residual process is expressed as a linear combination of scaled Gaussian kernels defined on a grid of spatial knots4, converging to a max-stable process asymptotically as the number of knots grows infinitely large. Here a consistent 0.5-degree knot grid covering the U.S. coast has been used to resolve the spatial residual process18, corresponding to the length scale and spatial extend of traditional historical TC storms (~500‚Äâkm). The residual process is built using all the knots at each tide gauge location. The length scale of the spatial residual dependence represents the spatial distance over which the residuals (differences between observed vs predicted values) remain correlated4, representing how far spatial influences persist before becoming negligible. Increasing BAYEX grid knot to 0.2 degrees or less could yield even more precise estimates for particular areas. However, such an increase comes with trade-offs as it is only computationally tractable by building the residual process using the nearest ten knots to each tide gauge station. Regional sensitivity analysis conducted for Florida indicates that increasing BAYEX grid knot from 0.5 to 0.2 degrees (while using ten knots at each tide gauge location) results in a reduction of the location (Œº) and scale (œÉ) parameters by< 5% and the shape parameter (Œæ) by ~15% when average across all tide gauge sites. While this increase in resolution could help resolve smaller length scales, the reduction in the number of spatial knots used decreases the ability of BAYEX to capture important regional dependence along many coastal regions. For example, in the U.S. South and East Coasts and Gulf Coast, major TC storms often track coastlines for hundreds of miles, affecting multiple tide gauges relatively far apart. Neglecting such regional dependences results in underestimated GEV parameters within such regions, particularly Œæ18.Technical ValidationThe adequacy and performance of BAYEX (and its underlying max-stable process) have been comprehensively assessed using tide gauge records, modeled storm surge simulations and synthetic storm data4,5. The max-stable assumption in BAYEX for representing storm surge extremes has also been confirmed through leave-one-out cross-validation based on tide gauge observations4,5. A full comparison of BAYEX skew surge (GEV) distribution parameters (and associated return period estimates) against estimates from conventional at-site GEV model based on Bayesian inference have been conducted for 208 tide gauges along the U.S. coastal areas18. Despite not including wave setup, which can be a key contributor to coastal extreme stillwater elevations, we find that 100-year ESL return levels based on BAYESL-TG/EXT usually exceed or are on par with FEMA estimates for tide gauge locations along the U.S. Gulf and East Coasts. Our comparison is less useful for the U.S. West Coast, where wave setup is a major contribution to sea level extremes (relative to storm surge events). There, not surprisingly, FEMA 100-year total water levels (and referred by FEMA as stillwater elevation) exceed BAYESL-TG/EX ESL estimates. FEMA estimates hold considerable authority in the U.S. However, to our knowledge, very few comparisons have been made against other methodological approaches, including in terms of uncertainty propagation and/or quantification. We hypothesize that this may be due to the absence of a single, centralized dataset ‚Äì data are dispersed across hundreds of FEMA Flood Insurance Studies - and the existing lack of a standardized approaches and/or metrics for storm surge and wave.

Time series AQI forecasting using Kalman-integrated Bi-GRU and Chi-square divergence optimization
                    Narmeen Fatima1,2¬†na1, Samia Nawaz Yousafzai3, Nadhem Nemri4, Hadeel Alsolai5, Shouki A. Ebad6, Shaymaa Sorour7, Yeonghyeon Gu8, Muhammad Syafrudin8 & ‚Ä¶Norma Latif Fitriyani8¬†na1¬†Show authors

Scientific Reports

volume¬†15, Article¬†number:¬†29157 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Computational scienceEnvironmental sciencesMathematics and computingProjection and prediction

AbstractAir pollution has become a pressing global concern, demanding accurate forecasting systems to safeguard public health. Existing AQI prediction models often falter due to missing data, high variability, and limited ability to handle distributional uncertainty. This study introduces a novel deep learning framework that integrates Kalman Attention with a Bi-Directional Gated Recurrent Unit (Bi-GRU) for robust AQI time-series forecasting. Unlike conventional attention mechanisms, Kalman Attention dynamically adjusts to data uncertainty, enhancing temporal feature weighting. Additionally, we incorporate a Chi-square Divergence-based regularization term into the loss function to explicitly minimize the distributional mismatch between predicted and actual pollutant levels‚Äìa contribution not explored in prior AQI models. Missing values are imputed using a pollutant-specific ARIMA model to preserve time-dependent trends. The proposed system is evaluated using real-world data from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (2022-2024) across six major pollutants (CO, NO\({_2}\), \(\hbox {SO}_2\), \(\hbox {O}_3\), \(\hbox {PM}_{10}\), \(\hbox {PM}_{2.5}\)) in the Denver-Aurora-Lakewood region. Experimental results demonstrate significant improvements over baseline models (LSTM, CNN-LSTM), achieving an \(\hbox {R}^2\) of 0.96794, MSE of 4.11\(\times\)10\(^{-7}\), and MAE of 0.000423. This work advances AQI forecasting by addressing uncertainty, distributional alignment, and missing data within a unified architecture, providing a scalable solution for environmental monitoring and policy support.

                        IntroductionOne of the most important issues facing the world today is air pollution, which has a substantial effect on human health, the environment, and economic stability. It originates from a variety of artificial sources that release toxic chemicals into the atmosphere, including industrial processes, vehicle emissions, and the burning of fossil fuels1,2,3. A standardized indicator that reduces complex pollutant concentrations to a single, easily interpretable number, the Air Quality Index (AQI) provides vital information for environmental policy and public safety4,5. Proactive health protection and urban planning rely on rapid and accurate AQI forecasts due to their direct correlation with respiratory and cardiovascular diseases. By creating a unique deep learning-based regression model that can handle missing data, capture uncertainty, and enhance temporal representation, this study seeks to solve the present shortcomings in AQI forecasting.The advent of technology has rendered the identification of AQI progressively dependent on Machine Learning (ML) and Deep Learning (DL). Recently, researchers have utilized DL in medical imaging6,7, natural language processing8, and precision agriculture9,10. For time-series AQI prediction, traditional statistical models such as ARIMA have been frequently used; nevertheless, they struggle with multivariate data dependencies and nonlinear correlations11,12. Improved forecasting accuracy has been demonstrated with deep learning (DL) techniques such as LSTM, Bi-LSTM, CNN-LSTM, and hybrid models optimized by evolutionary algorithms (e.g., GA-ELM, BSMO)13,14,15,16. Many, on the other hand, struggle with overfitting, poor cross-regional generalization, or the inability to efficiently manage noisy and imperfect data. Although most models employ fixed techniques that overlook the dynamic uncertainty in environmental data, models that leverage attention mechanisms show promise in valuing temporal aspects17,18. Moreover, statistical divergence metrics are rarely incorporated into current loss functions to enhance forecast calibration. Recent research suggests a gap in the integration of distribution-sensitive learning and adaptive attention for AQI modeling19. Further highlighting the necessity for strong spatiotemporal frameworks that can generalize across locations while preserving forecast accuracy in noisy data situations are the results in20 and21.In order to close these gaps, this study presents a novel regression framework that improves distributional learning by combining Chi-Square Divergence with a Bi-Directional Gated Recurrent Unit (Bi-GRU) network and Kalman Attention. Kalman Attention refines temporal focus and increases robustness to noise by dynamically adjusting attention weights based on changing uncertainty, in contrast to static attention mechanisms22. Better model generalization and prediction stability are made possible by the Chi-Square Divergence component, which calculates the difference between the actual and anticipated pollutant distributions23. By addressing the issues of sequential dependencies, uncertainty estimates, and unbalanced pollutant dynamics within a single architecture, this combination represents a substantial improvement over earlier approaches.A two-stage pipeline makes up the suggested system. Prior to feature scaling to normalize pollutant concentrations, missing values are first imputed using the Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (ARIMA) model, which is based on temporal continuity. Second, the Kalman Attention Bi-Gated Recurrent Unit (Bi-GRU) model optimizes the prediction output by processing the sequential input and applying a regression layer that is aware of divergence. The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency‚Äôs (EPA) dataset is openly accessible, comprising hourly pollutant data (CO, NO2, SO2, O3, PM10, PM2.5) collected from the Denver‚ÄìAurora‚ÄìLakewood region for the period 2022‚Äì2024. The model is evaluated using metrics such as \(R^2\), Mean Squared Error (MSE), and Mean Absolute Error (MAE) after being trained and validated using a rolling window technique.The following research questions serve as the basis for this investigation: RQ1: In comparison to conventional DL models, can AQI forecasting be enhanced by incorporating Kalman Attention into Bi-GRU? RQ2: Does the alignment of estimated and real pollutant distributions by the application of Chi-Square Divergence improve prediction performance? RQ3: How does the model compare to leading baselines across a variety of contaminants and metrics?.The remainder of this paper is organized as follows: Section 2 reviews previous research on AQI pollution estimation and highlights the research deficit. Section 3 describes the suggested methodology, including the regression algorithm used. Section 4 assesses the system‚Äôs performance through internal analysis and comparison with alternative methods. Finally, Section 6 presents the conclusion.Literature reviewThis section will cover numerous techniques and strategies for determining the concentrations of different air pollutants and AQI. Numerous studies have been conducted to investigate the impact of air pollution on the environment and human health, as well as to develop effective methods for forecasting air quality.Traditional modelsThe study24 sought to demonstrate the value of LSTM and Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (ARIMA) models in respiratory disease prediction. According to the study, LSTM outperforms ARIMA in terms of Root Mean Square Error (RMSE), particularly when working with longer datasets. The study presents a prediction method for ozone level forecasting that consists of AR, NLAR, and ARMA models, as well as STL decomposition. Hourly data from four stations in Lima, collected between 2017 and 2019, have been preprocessed by MICE and are used in the study. Standard forecast models perform better than conventional methods, according to results showing high accuracy rates (CC > 0.94) and low RMSE/MAE values25.Deep learning approachesA work highlights the importance of interpretability for AI-driven assessments of mental health across different populations based on air quality and weather variables26. We can evaluate the predicted association between air pollution, weather, and hospitalized individuals with mental problems by using a deep neural network. The study27 examines the significant impact of environmental influences on mental health, particularly in relation to hospital admissions.A study introduced the GT-LSTM model, a DL framework suitable for predicting different types of air pollution28. By learning about dynamic changes in air pollution for temporal dependency modeling, this study enhances the accuracy of air quality predictions. The study29 proposed an LSTM-NN model in combination with a novel wind-sensitive attention mechanism to predict the concentrations of the air pollutant PM2.5. The study demonstrates how the attention mechanism of the LSTM model enhances prediction accuracy by strengthening the model‚Äôs ability to focus on key temporal dependencies. Many prediction methods have failed due to overfitting problems and local optimum solutions that are locked in by feature selection. The proposed model30 solves the optimal local problem to choose the most beneficial characteristics. The Pollution Control Board has provided data on the air quality in various cities. The normalization process has been used to fill in the missing values in the dataset. The input has been more thoroughly represented using the CNN model. The BSMO methodology selected features based on balancing attributes and passed them to BI-LSTM (Bidirectional LSTM), which predicted air quality using an index measure. The suggested hybrid BSMO with BI-LSTM has demonstrated effective performance in AQI prediction. Similarly, Delhi‚Äôs AQI was predicted using the LSTM-GRU model31.Similarly, the study estimates air quality using GA-Optimized Extreme Learning Machine32 in combination with other models. However, the GA-KELM model has yielded faster and more accurate results than the present approach. The rapid technological development of smart cities pollutes the environment in several ways. More specifically, the emissions from manufacturing companies and transportation have increased air pollution33.A dual-microphone active noise cancellation system utilizing Doppler assimilation was presented by34, illustrating how hybrid learning approaches can improve real-time sensor data processing. The study‚Äôs methodology has implications for time-sensitive environmental forecasting systems, such as those used in air quality monitoring, even if its primary focus is acoustic noise.Hybrid modelsThe study35 developed a novel healthcare system that alerts patients to impending asthma attacks and predicts and prevents them using state-of-the-art machine-learning algorithms. A new ensemble forecasting approach that forecasts \(\hbox {PM}_{2.5}\) by combining three ensemble methods with six independent time-series models. Using Pakistani city data from 2019 to 2023, the ESMV model generated daily forecasts that outperformed individual models in every location with exceptional performance metrics (MAPE 0.1679-0.2167, RMSE 20.32-48.31)36.The government highly recommends measuring AQI in polluted areas, and the proposed model37 offers an artificial intelligence-based data analysis method for air quality forecasting that integrates machine learning. It has combined the neural network and decision tree models to attain a high level of prediction accuracy. Similarly, research38 employed an LSTM and a deep autoencoder to forecast PM concentrations in South Korea from 2015 to 2018 while also assessing air quality on a weekly basis. The average PM concentration level has been predicted during a continuous 10-day period. The best DAE performance has been found at a batch size of 64. Experiments with the technology in question have demonstrated better prediction performance.10 created a multi-method framework to assess the effects of thermal power plant effluents on vegetation‚Äôs air quality by combining chemometric approaches, remote sensing, and machine learning. This hybrid approach demonstrates the effectiveness of combining environmental monitoring and artificial intelligence in understanding the ecological stress caused by pollutants. Similarly, Pragasan and Ganesan39 identified pollution-tolerant plant species for establishing greenbelts and assessed air pollutant concentrations. Their research serves as an example of a hybrid mitigation technique based on natural principles that aligns with the goals of predictive modeling.The prediction of air quality index (AQI) has been successfully enhanced by statistical and DL models in numerous studies. However, three critical challenges continue to persist: (i) the management of environmental data missingness and noise, (ii) the modeling of temporal dependencies across various timescales, and (iii) the optimization of prediction under uncertain conditions. Most existing models stumble because they can‚Äôt learn on the fly and overlook how input data is distributed, thereby missing subtle shifts. This study builds on that shortcoming by introducing a novel attention layer that leverages Chi-Square Divergence to overcome those hurdles. By weaving together feature dependencies and distribution gaps, the new method aims to deliver sharper, steadier AQI forecasts regardless of changing scene conditions.MethodologyOverall architectureThe suggested regression model would employ a Bi-Directional GRU to assess the level of toxicity present in the atmosphere and predict air quality in AQI units. Existing studies in air quality forecasting have encountered issues such as a large number of missing observations and numerous missing attributes in the data, as well as instability in predictions. Additionally, past studies have identified small regions and have not developed generalized forecasting models. These barriers inspire the research, which aims to enhance the efficiency of prediction by utilizing a complex regression technique. This is achieved by the proposed method through improved data preprocessing based on the ARIMA model to accommodate missing values, and regression is performed using the new Kalman Attention Bi-Directional GRU with Modified Chi-Squared Divergence, aiming to achieve more consistent air quality predictions.Data preprocessing and regression techniques are the two phases in the recommended process. The dataset utilized in this study contains missing values. Imputation of missing values is performed using the ARIMA model, and data subject to scaling is adjusted to decrease the degree of complexity. During the scaling process, discrete variables are adjusted to achieve a predetermined limit. ARIMA will rely on the time-series trends of data to predict and fill out missing values. Missed values are not handled well; they can lead to incorrect predictions and issues with real-time data. The Kalman Attention module in the modified Bi-Directional GRU is employed to facilitate efficient AQI prediction. This model has been specifically designed to match specific pollutant characteristics with available data on pollution collected using advanced training methods and self-feedback connections. To accommodate a longer series of input data, reduce the number of model parameters, and achieve greater efficiency, the Chi-square divergence is incorporated. The proposed approach can make efficient predictions by drastically reducing the model‚Äôs complexity, as it uses less memory, and the Bi-Directional GRU is faster to train. The amount of pollution concentration determines the AQI level as good, moderate, or severe. The dataset comprises hourly and daily AQI records from various stations in multiple cities. The data that the proposed model works with have the values of the concentrations of dangerous gases and AQI indices. Missing values are imputed, and the model is tested and trained. The prediction procedure is then completed using a regression analysis model. The proposed regression model captures AQI levels based on the concentrations of contaminants in the air by utilizing the novel Kalman Attention Bi-Directional GRU with a modified Chi-Square Divergence. The model is evaluated in terms of MSE and MAE as a measure of its performance, as indicated by metrics such as \(\hbox {R}^2\). By reducing the error in the discrepancy between the expected and actual AQI values, the model ensures more accurate forecasting based on all measurements.The general architecture of the suggested method for air quality forecasting is depicted in Fig. 1, which also includes information on the regression model pipeline, which includes ARIMA and Bi-GRU, and the data preprocessing processes (such as feature scaling and missing values checking). The complete stepwise modeling pipeline, including preprocessing, sequence generation, and the Kalman-Attention Bi-GRU regression with Chi-square Divergence, is formally presented in Algorithm¬†1.Fig. 1The overall structure of the suggested approach.Full size imageAlgorithm 1Kalman-Attention Bi-GRU with Chi-Square Divergence for AQI ForecastingFull size imageDataset descriptionThe dataset used in this study was obtained from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA, http://www.epa.gov), which included air quality data for the Denver‚ÄìAurora‚ÄìLakewood area from January 1, 2022, to January 1, 2024. It includes the related calculated Air Quality Index (AQI) and hourly pollutant data of CO, NO2, SO2, O3, PM10, and PM2.5. The EPA‚Äôs Air Quality System (AQS) was used to retrieve the data, and the deployed sensors were calibrated in accordance with EPA guidelines. For the two years, the first-time series had roughly 17,520 hourly observations for each contaminant.Exploratory data analysisIn this study, the air quality data fluctuations were analyzed using exploratory data analysis (EDA). Figure 2 depicts overall variations in air pollutants from 2022 to 2024. The data exhibit fluctuations over time, indicating seasonal variations and pollution events. Despite periods of relatively low pollution, the graph reveals instances of elevated concentrations, suggesting occasional poor air quality. AQI trends over four time periods from 2022 to 2024 are shown in Fig. 3. Hourly AQI readings with high-frequency spikes are displayed in the top subplot, signifying brief pollution episodes. Daily averages, which level out some volatility but still highlight recurrent peaks, are shown in the second subplot. Weekly averages are displayed in the third subplot, which displays moderate variability and short-term trends. The long-term trend, characterized by a comparatively consistent AQI of 70, is depicted in the bottom subplot, which displays monthly averages.The trends highlight the impact of vehicular emissions, industrial activities, and meteorological factors on pollutant levels. Given that CO and \(\hbox {NO}_2\) originate primarily from automobile emissions, a strong correlation is expected between these two pollutants. Similarly, \(\hbox {PM}_{10}\) and \(\hbox {PM}_{2.5}\) often display synchronized trends, as they share familiar emission sources.Comparison between the level of pollutants on holidays and on non-holidays was made as well, and general trends in the level of pollutants were analyzed. As the data show, the situation on public holidays typically does not reach the same high levels of pollution. As a result of reduced automobile pollution and industrial activity, it was indicated that the average concentration of CO during the holiday was 15% lower compared to that on non-holiday days. The average concentration of \(\hbox {NO}_2\) decreased by approximately 10% during the vacation period due to a decline in transportation and industrial activity. Pollution rates were observed to lower by 12‚Äì18% during holidays in cases of \(\hbox {PM}_{2.5}\) and \(\hbox {PM}_{10}\), meaning that pollution sources, e.g., industrial emissions and vehicle traffic, got reduced. The cause of this reduction in the number of pollutants is reduced vehicle traffic, industrial practices, and other anthropogenic sources of pollution, which were reduced on the days of public holidays, implying that public holidays provide an opportunity to improve air quality in urban air.These findings underscore the importance of adopting effective pollution control practices to mitigate the decline in urban air quality. The correlation of most pollutant pairings is shown in the correlation matrix in Fig. 4. The data was preprocessed in order to manage the missing records, remove negative or incorrect entries, and make the timestamps of pollutant categories match. Due to the high quality of EPA monitoring, slight imputation was required, and time synchronization enabled the creation of continuous, multi-pollutant profiles over a three-year period. The dataset is ideal for evaluating long-term pollution dynamics in an urban setting and examining temporal trends. There is a noticeable decrease in the average concentration of pollutants, which can be attributed to either regional mitigation initiatives or better emissions controls. Due to less atmospheric dispersion and increased fuel combustion for heating, there is significant seasonal variance. Early spring and winter are the dual seasonal peaks of several pollutants, which correspond with transportation emissions and weather inversions. Weekend concentrations are marginally lower, according to smoothed data, likely due to reduced traffic and industrial activities. Despite their subtlety, these cycles add to the data‚Äôs weekly autocorrelation. Consistent across all pollutants, there are notable decreases on national holidays (such as Thanksgiving and Independence Day), which may indicate less human activity. Post-holiday increases have some implications for rebound traffic and industrial impacts. Temporary jumps are associated with recognized environmental events, such as winter inversion layers and smoke from wildfires in woodland areas. The episodes are necessary to understand the highest exposure risks. In some cases, the data may be missing due to EPA sensor failures or quality control flags. These small gaps were filled in through linear interpolation without altering the temporal patterns. The dataset can be used not only to forecast trends but also to detect seasonal anomalies, as it exhibits complex temporal dynamics. The characterization enhances the reproducibility of time-series modeling and increases the transparency of data selection. Other theorists and practitioners have recommended practices in line with this extensive temporal decomposition procedure, as seen in40, which analyzes multi-scale trends and seasonal components of energy measurements, and41, which examines calendar effects in time-series forecasting. These websites provided valuable ideas concerning how to handle and present complex environmental data.Fig. 2Daily air quality from 2022 to 2024.Full size imageFig. 3Hourly, Daily, Weekly, and Monthly AQI Trends from 2022 to 2024.Full size imageFig. 4Correlation between Pollutants.Full size imagePre-processing with ARIMAData preprocessing includes feature scaling and checking for missing values. Where the missing data is somehow known, the data values of pollution are noted discretely. The forecasting and filling in missing data using the ARIMA model effectively addresses these missing values by employing an imputation method. Scaling the features reduces the model‚Äôs complexity. With ARIMA as the imputation method, the replaced data is considered more reliable, as patterns of the missing data are accurately forecasted by ARIMA, allowing for further analysis. Addressing missing values and feature scaling are two aspects of data preprocessing. Discrete values are used to store pollution data, and missing values are common in datasets. The study employed a column-wise imputation method utilizing AutoRegressive Integrated Moving Average (ARIMA) models as univariate time series for pollution data. The study commenced with Augmented Dickey-Fuller tests to assess stationarity, followed by data differencing when the tests indicated non-stationarity. A grid search method identified the optimal ARIMA(p, d, q) parameters for each pollutant by minimizing the Akaike Information Criterion, thereby achieving maximum accuracy while avoiding complexity issues. The experimental parameter constraints encompassed p ranging from 1 to 5, d between 0 and 2, and q from 0 to 3. The selected models were used to forecast and impute missing data points based on prior observations, thereby maintaining temporal relationships regardless of external factors. The post-imputation investigation indicated that the estimated values maintained pollutant behavior patterns and preserved both seasonal changes and periodic trends.The selected imputation technique employs column-wise ARIMA-based methods rather than conventional linear interpolation or mean replacement, as it concurrently addresses time-dependent correlations while producing accurate projections. The application of ARIMA preserved the distinct historical trends for each pollutant, which is crucial for subsequent forecasting activities reliant on pattern retention. ARIMA is utilized to predict and impute missing values by leveraging the temporal patterns in the dataset. ARIMA models time-series data derived from historical values and trends, and it predicts missing data points by fitting a statistical model to the observed data. Unlike GANs, which rely on a generative structure with a generator and discriminator, ARIMA directly imputes missing values by identifying the relationships in the data over time.To predict missing values in the dataset, this study employed the statistical model ARIMA. For a time series \(Y_a\), an ARIMA model is represented by the given equation:$$\begin{aligned} Y_a=b+\sum _{x=1}^{p}{\phi _xY_{t-x}}+\sum _{y=1}^{q}{\theta _j\epsilon _{t-y}}+\epsilon _t \end{aligned}$$
                    (1)
                Let \(Y_a\) be the observed values and \(M_t\) represent the missing values (where \(M_t = 1\) if missing, and \(M_t = 0\) otherwise). The missing values at time t can be imputed by applying the ARIMA model to the known values.$$\begin{aligned} \widehat{Y_t}=\hat{c}+\sum _{x=1}^{p}\widehat{\phi _i}Y_{t-i}+\sum _{y=1}^{q}\widehat{\theta _j}\epsilon _{t-j} \end{aligned}$$
                    (2)
                The constant term in the model autoregressive moving average can be estimated as \(\hat{c}\), whereas \(\widehat{Yt}\) is the highest value of the time series at time t. Autoregressive (AR) f is denoted by an autoregressive component of size p, i.e., the summation of all the terms \(\sum _{x=1}^{p} \widehat{\phi _i} Y_{t-i}\). The moving average (MA) part with order q is coded as the \(\sum _{y=1}^{q} \widehat{\theta _j} \epsilon _{t-j}\) and it is the contribution of past forecast errors \(\epsilon _{t-j}\) weighted by the estimated parameters \(\widehat{\theta _j}\). With data of time series values that are not moving, the model is effective. The ARIMA model is generated as an effect of the occasion on a non-stationary time series, especially to make it stationary through differentiation methods.The estimation of the value of the time series in 2 locations of the missing data, at time t, is represented by \(\widehat{Y_t}\). Imputation is performed based on the associations found in the surrounding data points.The ARMA model is employed to make predictions \(\widehat{Y_t}\) using the history of observed values and errors in forecasting. These forecasted values are subsequently merged with the observed data \(D_{\text {observed}}\) to create a more complete dataset \(D_{\text {complete}}\). This technique is beneficial in cases where parts of the data are missing or require forecasting, allowing for data reconstruction or completion for subsequent analysis. The union symbol \(\cup\) denotes the addition of the observed data set with these model-derived estimates.$$\begin{aligned} D_{complete}=D_{observed}\cup \widehat{Y_t} \end{aligned}$$
                    (3)
                Where \(D_{complete}\) is the dataset with both observed and imputed values, \(D_{observed}\) contains only the observed values, and \(\widehat{Y_t}\) represents the imputed missing values. A comparison of the daily Max 8-hour pollutant concentration before and after preprocessing is given in Table 1. Where NaN denotes the missing data, data imputation techniques were applied to handle missing values while preserving overall trends.Table 1 Comparison of Daily Max 8-hour Pollutant Concentration Before and After Preprocessing.Full size tableCorrelation coefficientAQI has been used to measure pollution on a daily basis. For any pollutant P, the air quality index is denoted by \(IAQI_p\). \(BP_H\) is the highest contaminant concentration limit, and \(BP_L\) is the lowest contaminant load limit, similar to \(C_P\). Corresponding to \(BP_H\) and \(BP_L\), \(IAQI_H\), and \(IAQI_L\) are called the air quality sub-indices.$$\begin{aligned} IAQI_p= & \frac{\left( IAQI_H-IAQI_L\right) }{\left( BP_H-BP_L\right) }\cdot \left( Cp-BP_L\right) +IAQI_L \end{aligned}$$
                    (4)
                $$\begin{aligned} AQI= & \max {\ \left\{ IAQI_1,IAQI_2,IAQI_3,\ldots ,IAQI_n\right\} } \end{aligned}$$
                    (5)
                $$\begin{aligned} AQI_{max}= & \max {\left( IAQI_{CO},IAQI_{NO_2},IAQI_{SO_2},IAQI_{O_3},IAQI_{PM_{2.5}}IAQI_{PM_{10}}\right) } \end{aligned}$$
                    (6)
                The correlation coefficient is a statistical measure of the degree to which two variables are related to each other. However, this study utilizes six pollutant variables and five weather variables. The impact of one pollutant on another, as well as the impact of one weather condition on another, is in addition to the impact of one pollutant on another. In practical deployments, leveraging edge computing or distributed systems may be necessary to meet the demands for processing power, ensuring that the model can scale for widespread use without compromising accuracy. Handling and processing large amounts of time-series air quality data in real time can present significant storage and processing challenges. Efficient data storage and retrieval systems will need to be implemented to handle high-frequency sensor data while ensuring minimal latency in prediction generation.The model was tested with data from specific regions such as the Denver-Aurora-Lakewood area. To be implemented in other areas, the hypothesis must be generalizable to other air pollution trends, local emission components, and sensor data peculiarities. There will be a need to enhance the model‚Äôs generalizability to other geographical locations in the future. The application of the AQI forecasting model in real-life practices will also involve compliance with local environmental regulations and data privacy laws, particularly when working with environmental and health-related information. As much as the model should be acceptable to people, it is necessary so that the model can be incorporated into the structures of public policies.Lastly, the infrastructure needed to implement this model of structure on a large scale, such as sensor networks, computational resources, and data storage, can be prohibitively expensive in certain geographic locations. To achieve widespread adoption, it will be necessary to develop affordable solutions and strategies that make them accessible to resource-strained societies. By eliminating these hurdles, the suggested system will become capable of handling tasks such as air quality monitoring, providing environmental policy guidance at both local and global levels, and implementing public health solutions and activities.ConclusionThe study proposes a new system that employs the attention mechanism of Kalman with a network of Bi-Directional Gated Recurrent Units (Bi-GRU), in which the loss function is optimized using Chi-Square Divergence. The methodology provides solutions to the most significant problems related to AQI forecasting, including the incorporation of temporal data dependency, handling missing data, and processing noisy or inconsistent data. The authors evaluated their proposed model on a day-to-day basis using pollution data from the U.S. EPA, which covers the Denver-Aurora-Lakewood area. The developed model was more effective than the traditional Bi-GRU, LSTM, and CNN-LSTM variations in experimental evaluation. An application of the modified attention model, based on the Chi-Square Divergence, resulted in necessary reductions of 15.3%, 12.7%, and 14.1% in MAE, \(\hbox {R}^2\), and MSE, respectively, compared to the best baseline model. The suggested model excels in capturing geographical and temporal patterns while identifying meaningful correspondences in multivariate records of the AQI dataset. We observed a distinct pattern of lower air pollution during holidays, which is consistent with the predictions of lower human activity, by measuring the variations in pollutant levels between holidays and non-holidays. This quantitative result provides insight into how human behavior impacts environmental health and validates the model‚Äôs ability to identify and measure changes in air quality over time. The suggested method exhibits a robust ability to monitor air quality in real-time and formulate operational strategies since it functions successfully with noisy and incomplete data. The forthcoming study will focus on developing a multimodal input system integrated with deployable edge computing for localized, time-sensitive predictions of air quality indices.

items.body:
By:  Simona Toci  |  EURACTIV Italia    8 Agosto 2025|18:11             
            
                
        
    Foto d'archivio. Gruppo di migranti entra in Ungheria, 2015. [G√©mes S√°ndor/SzomSzed, via Wikimedia Commons]

Nell‚Äôanniversario dello sbarco fortunato di 20.000 persone al porto di Bari, avvenuto 34 anni fa, si celebra purtroppo un ennesimo funerale nello stesso mare che √® diventato il pi√π mortale dei confini al mondo, il Mediterraneo.
Negli scorsi giorni sono morte tre persone nel canale di Sicilia, si sono gettate in mare nel tentativo di farsi vedere da una nave in lontananza, secondo quanto riportato dalla Guardia costiera, e il 5 agosto sulla spiaggia di Sotillo a Castell de Ferro a Grenada sono sbarcati una diecina di migranti, che anzich√© essere soccorsi, sono stati accerchiati dai bagnanti fino all‚Äôarrivo della polizia.
La gestione del fenomeno migratorio e le politiche che i governi mettono in atto sono lo specchio di una societ√† sempre pi√π radicalizzata, anche a causa dell‚Äôutilizzo strumentale da parte di alcuni partiti per accaparrarsi fette di elettorato sempre pi√π stanco e frustrato.
La tendenza securitaria √® trasversale agli Stati membri ‚Äì dalla Lega in Italia, al Front National in Francia, ad Alternative f√ºr Deutschland in Germania, Vox in Spagna ‚Äì e si traduce in politiche concrete come il protocollo Italia-Albania fortemente voluto dal Governo Meloni e la sospensione dell‚Äôaccordo Schengen in Germania rinnovato dal cancelliere Friedrich Merz con l‚Äôobiettivo esplicito di contrastare l‚Äôavanzata di AfD.
La migrazione in Europa: I numeri 
Dalla fuga dei profughi delle guerre jugoslave negli anni ‚Äô90 alla crisi siriana del 2015, la storia recente dell‚ÄôEuropa √® segnata da ondate migratorie diverse per origine e cause. Ai flussi dettati da conflitti si sono affiancate migrazioni economiche: dall‚ÄôAlbania post-Hoxha, in cerca di riscatto dopo il crollo del regime, fino alle partenze da Nord Africa, Asia e Sud America.

QFP e migrazione: la Commissione predilige un approccio securitario rispetto all‚Äôaccoglienza
Nel Quadro finanziario pluriennale 2028-2034¬†proposto dalla Commissione europea il 16 luglio scorso, 74 miliardi di euro sono dedicati alla sicurezza. Di questi, pi√π della met√†, vale a dire 48 miliardi, sono destinati al rafforzamento delle frontiere.
Il bilancio europeo a ‚Ä¶

Dal 2015 ad oggi, secondo quanto riportato da UNICEF, oltre 2,7 milioni di persone hanno attraversato il Mediterraneo per raggiungere il continente europeo. Pi√π di 31.700 non ce l‚Äôhanno fatta: il mare li ha inghiottiti, tra loro moltissimi bambini. Solo nei primi mesi del 2025 sono arrivati via mare pi√π di 36.000 migranti, di cui oltre 7.400 minori. Un flusso che mette in crisi sistemi d‚Äôaccoglienza gi√† fragili e incapaci di garantire percorsi di integrazione reale.
La rotta balcanica, crocevia di disperazione soprattutto per chi parte da Afghanistan, Pakistan e Siria, resta tra le pi√π battute e pericolose. Qui violenze da parte della polizia, respingimenti e abusi sono stati pi√π volte denunciati da Amnesty International. In Croazia, in particolare, si registrano espulsioni di massa verso Serbia e Bosnia, paesi fuori dall‚ÄôUE, in aperta violazione del diritto internazionale.
Eppure, mentre il dibattito politico e mediatico si concentra su sbarchi e immigrazione irregolare, spesso associata a criminalit√†, un paradosso resta evidente: molti Paesi europei dipendono dalla manodopera straniera per mantenere in vita interi settori economici.
La progressiva esternalizzazione delle frontiere 
L‚Äôesternalizzazione delle proprie frontiere e la cooperazione con Paesi terzi ‚Äì che molto spesso non rispettano i principi sanciti dalla CEDU ‚Äì sembrano essere una soluzione appetibile per la maggior parte dei paesi dell‚ÄôUE e anche per quelli ex UE, come il Regno Unito che sotto l‚Äôamministrazione Sunak aveva brevettato il ‚ÄúRwanda Bill‚Äú, poi cancellato dall‚Äôattuale primo ministro laburista Keir Starmer.
Questa politica √® stata in parte appoggiata dalla stessa Presidente della Commissione europea durante questo mandato. Ursula von der Leyen ha, infatti, pi√π volte elogiato il modello italo-albanese, promuovendo un approccio ‚Äúsecuritario‚Äù alla gestione del fenomeno migratorio ed stimolando ‚Äúsoluzioni innovative‚Äù per affrontare le sfide a livello dell‚ÄôUE.
Ma il protocollo tra Roma e Tirana, che trasferisce in territorio albanese le procedure di trattenimento e identificazione, mostra gi√† crepe e limiti ed √® stato messo in discussione dalla recente pronuncia della Corte di Giustizia dell‚ÄôUE.

Per la Corte di Giustizia dell'UE la definizione di Paese sicuro va verificata dai giudici, una sconfitta per Meloni
La designazione di un paese terzo come ‚ÄúPaese di origine sicuro‚Äù da parte di uno Stato membro dell‚ÄôUnione europea deve poter essere sottoposta a un controllo giurisdizionale effettivo. Lo ha stabilito la Corte di giustizia dell‚ÄôUnione europea, ‚Ä¶

Gli accordi con Paesi terzi, per√≤, non si fermano all‚ÄôAlbania. Il Memorandum Italia-Libia e l‚Äôintesa UE-Tunisia, cos√¨ come l‚Äôaccordo ‚Äústorico‚Äù fra Unione europea e Turchia, restano tra i pi√π controversi. In Libia, migliaia di migranti intercettati in mare sono stati riportati in centri di detenzione dove torture, abusi e sfruttamento sono sistematici. In Tunisia, l‚ÄôUE √® stata accusata di chiudere un occhio di fronte a detenzioni arbitrarie e violenze, mentre il presidente Kais Saied veniva accusato di alimentare una retorica razzista e discriminatoria.
La gestione dei flussi migratori resta al centro del dibattito politico nazionale ed europeo, ma non √® ancora una competenza pienamente comunitaria. Le politiche in materia continuano, infatti, ad essere vincolate al voto all‚Äôunanimit√† dei singoli Stati membri, un meccanismo che produce distorsioni, frena decisioni comuni e alimenta risposte frammentarie.
In assenza di una visione condivisa, l‚ÄôUnione europea continua a oscillare tra la retorica della sicurezza e l‚Äôurgenza di una politica migratoria davvero comune che sia realmente solidale e rispettosa dei diritti umani.

A Festambiente presentato il XIV rapporto nazionale ‚ÄúAnimali in citt√†‚Äù e premiati gli ‚Äúamici‚Äù degli animali

8 Agosto 2025

8 Agosto 2025
